instruction: Can the combination of surface functionalization, plasmonics, surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), and machine learning be considered a superior method for the recognition of normal and cancer cells compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the combination of surface functionalization, plasmonics, surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), and machine learning can be considered a superior method for the recognition of normal and cancer cells compared to traditional methods. This interdisciplinary approach utilizes the advanced techniques of surface functionalization and chemistry, plasmonics, and SERS to achieve high sensitivity and specificity in detecting and distinguishing normal and cancer cells. By functionalizing the surface of gold multibranched nanoparticles (AuMs) with different chemical groups, selective entrapping of biomolecules from cells cultivation media is achieved, providing information-rich inputs for machine learning methods and SERS-based cell recognition. The evaluation of convolutional neural networks (CNN) training results, along with ad hoc feature selection, indicates that the grafted functional groups offer specificity to proteins, nucleic acids, and lipids, which are responsible for cancer line identification. The dataset of SERS control spectra of normal and cancer cell metabolites was successfully classified by the trained CNN, achieving a 100% prediction accuracy in distinguishing between normal and cancer cells. This demonstrates the superiority of this advanced approach in the recognition of normal and cancer cells compared to traditional methods.
